newsitem.title: UK: Copper LME spread narrowed after match-off, trader.
newsitem.headline: Copper LME spread narrowed after match-off, trader.

text.p: Monday's dramatic collapse in copper's backwardation on the London Metal Exchange (LME) - with the spread more than halving - may have been because of an off-market match-off, traders said on Tuesday.
The speed and ferocity of the contraction in cash/May and cash/threes suggests that the tightness had been defused by the major long and short coming to an agreement, they said.
"Basically, the way the market went one can assume that - whether it happened is another matter, though," one said.
Prior to Monday's second official ring, copper's cash to three months backwardation was as high as $210 as a series of highly sensitive prompt dates approached.
The nearby squeeze had been relentless, with major investment houses said to be on the long side of the market.
But if there was a match-off, or "ring-out", between a long and a short the heat would have been taken out of the market almost immediately.
Cash/threes contracted viciously, and by Tuesday midday was either side of $70, while cash/May eased from $100 Monday to $5 today.
Traders said it was impossible to be sure what had taken place and why, partly because of the expansion in LME trading that has taken place over the last decade.
Major off-market players now account for vast amounts of business, which would not necessarily end up being transacted on the LME floor, other than what is not netted off.
"We have no way of knowing for sure (that it was a "ring-out"). It just looks that way," another trader said.
Others were unsure, meanwhile, saying the tightness could flare up again, as the May/three months spread remains fairly high.
Some said that the short market position is perpetually being rolled forward. It dates back to end-October 1996, and may now be residing at the end of July, they said.
Also, short-term fundamantals suggest that short selling copper will be a risky venture.
Chile's Escondida and Quebrada Blanca mines are suffering from strikes. There are disputes in North America, while the giant Kennecott smelter in Utah is closed for repairs.
Against this backdrop LME stocks are falling, and there is the ever-present possibility of major Chinese purchases if the price is right.
